rating_criteria.description: Diabetes is rated based on treatment requirements and regulation of activities

levels.criteria: Requiring insulin and restricted diet, or oral hypoglycemic agent and restricted diet
Requiring insulin, restricted diet, and regulation of activities

Requiring insulin, restricted diet, and regulation of activities with episodes of ketoacidosis or hypoglycemic reactions requiring one or two hospitalizations per year or twice a month visits to a diabetic care provider, plus complications that would not be compensable if separately evaluated

Requiring more than one daily injection of insulin, restricted diet, and regulation of activities (avoidance of strenuous occupational and recreational activities) with episodes of ketoacidosis or hypoglycemic reactions requiring at least three hospitalizations per year or weekly visits to a diabetic care provider, plus either progressive loss of weight and strength or complications that would be compensable if separately evaluated

regulation_of_activities.definition: Avoidance of strenuous occupational and recreational activities
regulation_of_activities.critical_note: This must be MEDICALLY REQUIRED and documented by a physician
examples: Doctor's order to avoid strenuous exercise
Cannot perform certain work activities due to diabetes
regulation_of_activities.common_mistake: Self-imposed activity restrictions do NOT count - must be doctor-ordered

key_definitions.ketoacidosis: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) - dangerous buildup of ketones in blood

types_of_diabetes.description: Autoimmune destruction of insulin-producing cells; requires insulin
Insulin resistance; may be controlled with diet, oral meds, or insulin

common_symptoms: Numbness or tingling in hands or feet

secondary_conditions.description: Diabetes commonly causes or aggravates many secondary conditions

common_complications.description: Nerve damage causing numbness, pain, weakness in extremities
Eye damage potentially causing vision loss
High blood pressure often associated with diabetes
Heart disease risk increased by diabetes

secondary_conditions.rating_note: Complications are rated separately UNLESS they are non-compensable, in which case they support a higher diabetes rating

agent_orange.conditions: Veterans exposed to Agent Orange in Vietnam, Thailand (certain bases), Korean DMZ, or other qualifying locations
agent_orange.note: No nexus letter required for presumptive connection

tips_for_veterans: Document ALL medications - insulin type, dosage, frequency
Get written doctor's orders for any activity restrictions
Keep records of blood sugar logs showing highs and lows
Document any hospitalizations for ketoacidosis or hypoglycemia
Track frequency of diabetic care provider visits
List ALL complications - neuropathy, vision, kidney, ED
Request separate evaluations for compensable complications
If you have secondary conditions, file for them separately
Document how diabetes affects your work and daily activities
Keep records of diet restrictions prescribed by doctor
common_mistakes: Not getting written medical orders for activity restrictions
Failing to document hospitalizations for diabetic emergencies
Self-restricting activities without doctor's orders (doesn't count)

all_three_required: Regulation of activities (MUST be medically ordered)
40_percent_requirements.common_denial_reason: Veteran restricts own activities but lacks doctor's written order
40_percent_requirements.tip: Ask your doctor to document in writing that you must avoid strenuous activities due to diabetes

important_notes: Regulation of activities MUST be prescribed by a physician to count
Type 2 Diabetes is presumptive for Agent Orange exposure
Complications should be rated separately if compensable (10%+)
Peripheral neuropathy is extremely common secondary condition
Blood sugar logs and A1C results support claim
Hospitalizations for diabetic emergencies are key for higher ratings
